title: 103_hr4698
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. TERMINATION OF TOBACCO PRICE SUPPORT AND MARKETING QUOTAS." is about the termination of tobacco price support and marketing quotas. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to terminate tobacco price support. This includes removing references to tobacco in various sections and adding "or tobacco" in one section. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to terminate tobacco price support, including the repeal of tobacco marketing quotas and conforming amendments to remove references to tobacco in various sections. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to terminate tobacco price support, including the repeal of tobacco marketing quotas and conforming amendments to remove references to tobacco in various sections. Amendments include striking references to tobacco in different paragraphs and sections, with the effective date set for January 1, 1995. The Secretary of Agriculture will end loan agreements with tobacco producer associations and dispose of funds in the No Net Cost Tobacco Fund. Producers will still be liable under existing laws. SEC. 2. DISALLOWANCE OF DEDUCTION FOR CERTAIN ADVERTISING EXPENSES FOR TOBACCO PRODUCTS. Deduction Disallowed for advertising expenses related to tobacco products. New section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No deduction allowed for consumer sales promotions of tobacco products, including various advertising methods like radio, TV commercials, billboards, and point-of-purchase displays. Deductions are allowed for travel expenses, entertainment, gifts, promotion expenses, advertising promotion allowances, premiums, samples, and sponsorships of events under a registered brand name of a tobacco product. The brand name must be the name of a corporation existing on July 1, 1994 to market nontobacco products or display on various items. Payment for tobacco product placement in movies or plays is restricted. Tobacco product refers to cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco, and pipes. The definition of 'tobacco product' includes cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco, pipe tobacco, or similar products. The terms 'cigarette', 'cigar', and 'smokeless tobacco' are defined in section 5702. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for part IX. Sec. 280I disallows deduction for certain advertising expenses for tobacco products. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, a new section establishes the Anti-Tobacco Use Trust Fund under Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Anti-Tobacco Use Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by 50% of revenue increase from disallowing tobacco advertising deductions. It includes an Anti-Drugs in Schools Account for related expenses. The Anti-Drugs in Schools Account receives 50% of appropriations from the Anti-Tobacco Use Trust Fund for programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Additionally, the Anti-Tobacco Use Advertising Account is established within the Trust Fund for related expenses. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers 50% of appropriations to the Anti-Tobacco Use Advertising Account for the program under the Public Health Service Act. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for the subchapter. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish an anti-tobacco advertising campaign funded by the Anti-Tobacco Use Trust Fund. The Secretary will conduct an advertising program to educate the public on the health risks of tobacco use.
